post_text: Last year DD2 changed from in-person registration to online. Although moving forward with technology was more convenient, it presented a new challenge for many PTAs in regard to selling memberships. Membership dropped from 10,000+ members to 8,000+. Fast forward to days of COVID & eLearning/Virtual Academy, the whole district is only at 1767 members! We thought last year was a challenge, but this year is a whole new ballgame! Your PTAs are working hard behind the scenes, still supporting your students and teachers. If you can, please look for your school's PTA MemberHub store link, and buy a membership! Most average $5 and will allow you to have a say in PTA votes, support your PTA, and their efforts in the schools. Virtual Academy is still part of your home-based school! Be involved and have a say! If you can volunteer with the PTA, most committees and planning this year can be done right from your couch in a virtual meeting! If ever there was a year to try out, this is the year! Donate, buy a membership, or sign up! #HowDoYouPTA

Funding Reform must happen now for our students! Be a voice for our communities.

Do you know how lawmakers avoid funding the base student cost created in 1977 called the Education Finance Act. Lawmakers use a funding formula but house budget writers since 2010 have reduced the mandated cost to $2,400 (2017) per student by ‚Äúdetermining‚Äù in a budget proviso they want base spending to be lower. In other words, they get around the law by simply rewriting the mandate year after year. In 2017-18, it meant 721,401 students in K-12 schools will get $421.3 million less than what they are supposed to get by law.
Credit given to: Andy Brack ¬∑ 03/10/2017

Here you will find "How a Bill Becomes a Law" understanding this process is one step to help us all in becoming more informed and having our voices heard.

October is Health Literacy Month

Health Literacy Month is a time for organizations and individuals to promote the importance of understandable health information and a chance for you to tell the world what you're doing too!

The theme for Health Literacy Month is "Be a Health Literacy Hero." It's about taking action and finding ways to improve health communication. Health Literacy Heroes are individuals, teams, or organizations who not only identify health literacy problems but also act to solve them. You can help by recognizing and cheering on those you consider as Health Literacy Heroes. Please share your story and projects as well.

http://www.healthliteracymonth.org/

For more information contact: bscott@iha4health.org

Dorchester School District Two will close all schools and district facilities on Friday, September 8th, Monday, September 11th, and Tuesday, September 12th due to Hurricane Irma impacting our area. This decision is being made in an abundance of caution to allow our parents and employees the opportunity to prepare for the safety of their families and in anticipation of the storm. All extra-curricular activities, events, and extended day programs scheduled for Friday through Tuesday are also cancelled.

School district leaders will continue to monitor weather conditions and possible storm impact on our community closely to make decisions concerning future cancellations if necessary. Any announcements will be made using the school district‚Äôs automated telephone system, the district website, social media and local media outlets.

As always, the safety of our students and employees is the primary factor in all decisions made.

Students in Dorchester District Two will NOT be required to wear uniforms for the 2017-2018 school year. We have learned that there has been a bill pre-filed in the state legislature to require all public school students to wear uniforms and this has been reported by a Columbia television station. Please know that consideration of any pre-filed bills could not occur until the next legislative session in January 2018. A bill of this nature is quite often introduced in the legislature but has never been passed.

"Our Roots Run Deep"

SCPTA has been advocating for our children, parents and teachers for 94 years-which fits this year's theme..."Our Roots Run Deep". While we are a seasoned association, we see the need to constantly grow, change and develop new ideas to enhance our mission.

Please take advantage of this once-a-year opportunity to learn from our many speakers and workshops, to connect by sharing ideas, success stories, even not-quite success stories (because they help us learn), and celebrate the accomplishments of committed volunteers.

Join us as we celebrate our roots and the impact made over the past 120 years.
